title: Data Science & AI Comprehensive Bank
description: Expanded 150-question bank for FBLA Objective Test preparation.

questions.text: Which property of the mean makes it unique compared to the median in a skewed distribution?
options: It is always the exact middle value of the dataset
It minimizes the sum of squared deviations of values
It is unaffected by extremely high or low outliers
It represents the most frequent value in the set

questions.text: In a standard normal distribution, what percentage of data falls within two standard deviations of the mean?
options: Approximately 68 percent of the total data
Approximately 95 percent of the total data
Approximately 99 percent of the total data
Approximately 50 percent of the total data

questions.text: Two events are considered mutually exclusive if which of the following conditions is true?
options: The occurrence of one event changes the other
Both events cannot occur at the same time
The probability of both events is exactly one
One event must happen for the other to start

questions.text: What does a Z-score of -1.5 indicate about a specific data point in a distribution?
options: The value is 1.5 units above the mean
The value is 1.5 standard deviations below the mean
The value has a 1.5 percent chance of occurring
The value is exactly 1.5 times the median

questions.text: Which statistical test is most appropriate for comparing the means of more than two groups?
options: The standard Independent Samples t-test
The Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) test
The Pearson correlation coefficient test
The simple linear regression analysis

questions.text: What is the primary difference between a population parameter and a sample statistic?
options: The parameter is estimated, the statistic is fixed
The parameter describes the whole, the statistic a part
The parameter is always larger than the statistic
The parameter is qualitative, the statistic is numeric

questions.text: In hypothesis testing, a Type I error occurs when a researcher takes which action?
options: Fails to reject a null hypothesis that is false
Rejects a null hypothesis that is actually true
Accepts an alternative hypothesis that is false
Sets the significance level at a value above 0.5

questions.text: The Central Limit Theorem states that as sample size increases, the sampling distribution of the mean:
options: Becomes more skewed toward the outliers
Approaches a normal distribution shape
Has a larger standard deviation than the population
Matches the exact shape of the original population

questions.text: Which of the following describes the 'Law of Large Numbers' in probability theory?
options: Large samples will always have a mean of zero
Sample means converge to the population mean
Probability increases as the sample size grows
Small samples are more accurate than large ones

questions.text: A correlation coefficient of -0.85 between two variables suggests which relationship?
options: A weak positive linear relationship
A strong negative linear relationship
A moderate positive linear relationship
No discernable linear relationship exists

questions.text: What is the result of multiplying the probability of two independent events?
options: The probability of either event occurring
The probability of both events occurring
The probability of neither event occurring
The average probability of the two events

questions.text: Which measure of dispersion is calculated by taking the square root of the variance?
options: The absolute range of the dataset
The standard deviation of the set
The interquartile range of the data
The mean absolute deviation of the set

questions.text: In a box plot, the 'box' itself represents which portion of the data distribution?
options: The range between the minimum and maximum
The middle 50 percent of the data (IQR)
The values within one standard deviation
The total frequency of all categorical data

questions.text: When using a 95% confidence interval, what does the '95%' specifically represent?
options: 95 percent of all data points fall in the interval
The probability that the true parameter is included
The margin of error relative to the sample size
The percentage of samples that will match the mean

questions.text: Which distribution is characterized by having only two possible outcomes for each trial?
options: The Poisson distribution for counts
The Binomial distribution for trials
The Normal distribution for variables
The Uniform distribution for chances

questions.text: If a dataset has a mean of 50 and a median of 30, the distribution is most likely:
options: Perfectly symmetrical like a bell curve
Positively skewed toward higher values
Negatively skewed toward lower values
Uniformly distributed across the range

questions.text: What is the probability of rolling a 3 or a 4 on a single fair six-sided die?
options: One-sixth (approximately 16.7 percent)
One-third (approximately 33.3 percent)
One-half (exactly 50.0 percent)
Two-thirds (approximately 66.7 percent)

questions.text: Which type of variable is 'Temperature measured in degrees Celsius' classified as?
options: Nominal or strictly categorical data
Interval or continuous numeric data
Ordinal or ranked qualitative data
Binary or strictly boolean data

questions.text: The 'Mode' of a dataset is defined as which of the following values?
options: The arithmetic average of all numbers
The value that appears most frequently
The middle point when data is ordered
The difference between high and low

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of a scatter plot in statistical analysis?
options: To show the distribution of a single variable
To visualize the relationship between two variables
To identify the most frequent category in a set
To calculate the exact mean of a population

questions.text: Which concept describes the likelihood of an event given that another event has already occurred?
options: Joint probability of independent sets
Conditional probability of related events
Marginal probability of single variables
Subjective probability of random trials

questions.text: In a right-skewed distribution, how do the mean, median, and mode typically relate?
options: The mean is less than the median
The mean is greater than the median
The mean and median are exactly equal
The mode is greater than the mean

questions.text: What is the term for a subset of individuals chosen from a larger population for study?
options: The parameter group of the study
The sample taken for analysis
The census of the entire population
The strata of the statistical group

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which technique is commonly used to reduce the dimensionality of a dataset in AI projects?
options: Simple Linear Regression Analysis
Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
Standard Gradient Descent Method
K-Nearest Neighbors Classification

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Why is 'Feature Scaling' important for algorithms like K-Nearest Neighbors?
options: It increases the total number of features
It prevents larger units from dominating distance
It removes all outliers from the dataset
It converts text data into binary format

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: In the context of AI, what does 'Data Normalization' typically involve?
options: Deleting all duplicate rows in a database
Rescaling numeric values to a [0,1] range
Converting all categorical data to integers
Adding random noise to improve privacy

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: What is the purpose of using a 'Confusion Matrix' in model evaluation?
options: To calculate the total training time of a model
To visualize performance on classification tasks
To determine the hardware requirements for AI
To generate synthetic data for testing purposes

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which metric is calculated as the ratio of true positives to the sum of true and false positives?
options: The Recall or sensitivity of the model
The Precision or exactness of the model
The Accuracy or overall correctness rate
The F1-Score or harmonic mean of results

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: What is 'Overfitting' in the context of machine learning model training?
options: The model performs poorly on training data
The model performs too well on training data only
The model takes too much memory to process
The model uses too many categorical variables

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which validation technique involves splitting data into 'k' subsets for repeated testing?
options: Simple Random Sampling validation
K-Fold Cross-Validation technique
Bootstrapping with replacement method
Leave-One-Out stratified validation

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: The 'Bias-Variance Tradeoff' refers to the tension between which two model properties?
options: Training speed and deployment latency
Under-fitting and over-fitting tendencies
Data volume and computational complexity
Linear logic and non-linear outputs

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which of these is a common strategy for handling missing values in a dataset?
options: Always deleting every row with a null
Imputing values with the mean or median
Ignoring the column in the final report
Adding a zero to every empty text field

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: What does a 'Residual' represent in a regression model analysis?
options: The sum of all predicted target values
The difference between observed and predicted
The total variance explained by the model
The coefficient of the independent variable

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which visualization is best for detecting outliers in a continuous variable?
options: A standard categorical bar chart
A box plot with extended whiskers
A pie chart showing proportions
A line graph of temporal changes

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: What is the primary function of 'One-Hot Encoding' in data preparation?
options: Reducing the memory usage of large integers
Converting categories into binary vectors
Removing duplicates from a SQL database
Encrypting sensitive data for Al models

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: In an AI context, what does the term 'Ground Truth' typically refer to?
options: The hardware specifications of the server
The actual known labels for the test data
The mathematical proof of an algorithm
The legal requirements for data storage

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which metric would be most useful for evaluating a model where false negatives are very costly?
options: The Precision of the model's predictions
The Recall or sensitivity of the model
The total number of true negative results
The training time per epoch of the model

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: What is the goal of 'Hyperparameter Tuning' in machine learning?
options: To clean the raw input data automatically
To find the best settings for the algorithm
To increase the speed of the GPU processing
To decrease the size of the training dataset

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: What is 'Regularization' used for in model development?
options: Increasing the complexity of neural layers
Preventing overfitting by penalizing weights
Decreasing the time needed for data loading
Improving the resolution of input images

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which type of analysis focuses on determining the impact of changing input variables on the output?
options: Descriptive statistical summary
Sensitivity analysis of variables
Exploratory data visualization
Historical trend documentation

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: In a dataset with high 'Collinearity', what is occurring between variables?
options: Variables have no relationship at all
Independent variables are highly correlated
The target variable is strictly binary
All data points are exactly the same

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: What does 'Data Augmentation' involve in computer vision tasks?
options: Deleting blurry images from the training set
Creating variations of images by rotating them
Labeling images using an automated script
Storing images in a compressed cloud drive

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which of the following is a symptom of 'Underfitting'?
options: High accuracy on training but low on test
Low accuracy on both training and test data
The model takes too long to reach a solution
The model is too complex for the hardware

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: What is the primary benefit of 'Standardizing' data (Mean=0, SD=1)?
options: It makes the data easier for humans to read
It ensures features share a common scale
It reduces the size of the overall dataset
It converts continuous data into categories

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: A ROC Curve (Receiver Operating Characteristic) plots which two values?
options: Precision versus Recall metrics
True Positive Rate versus False Positive Rate
Training Loss versus Validation Loss
Accuracy versus Computational Complexity

questions.category: Data Analysis and Statistics for AI
questions.text: Which term describes the process of selecting the most relevant features for a model?
options: Feature Engineering and design
Feature Selection and pruning
Feature Extraction and creation
Feature Transformation and scaling

questions.text: Which Python library is the standard for performing numeric calculations and array operations?
options: Matplotlib for visualization
NumPy for numerical computing
BeautifulSoup for web scraping
Flask for web development

questions.text: What is the primary use of the 'Pandas' library in a Data Science workflow?
options: Creating high-level neural network layers
Manipulating structured data via DataFrames
Writing scripts to control hardware robots
Managing cloud-based database connections

questions.text: Which environment is most popular for creating and sharing live code and visualizations?
options: Command Prompt or Terminal
Jupyter Notebook environment
Microsoft Word processor
Standard Windows Notepad

questions.text: In SQL, which command is used to combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column?
options: The GROUP BY command
The JOIN command
The UPDATE command
The SELECT command

questions.text: Which tool is primarily used for 'Big Data' processing across distributed clusters?
options: SQLite for local files
Apache Spark framework
Microsoft Excel software
Python Standard Library

questions.text: What is 'Scikit-Learn' specifically designed for in the Python ecosystem?
options: Deep Learning with large neural networks
Standard machine learning and data mining
Building interactive web dashboards
Automating tasks in the operating system

questions.text: Which SQL clause is used to filter results after an aggregation has been performed?
options: The WHERE clause
The HAVING clause
The FROM clause
The ORDER BY clause

questions.text: What is the main advantage of using 'Cloud Computing' (e.g., AWS, Azure) for AI training?
options: It eliminates the need for any internet
Scalable access to powerful GPU resources
It is always cheaper than local hardware
It guarantees that models will be biased

questions.text: Which library is most commonly used for creating static, interactive, and animated visualizations in Python?
options: The Pytest testing framework
The Matplotlib plotting library
The Django backend framework
The Requests HTTP library

questions.text: What is the purpose of 'GitHub' in a data science or software development project?
options: To host and version control code files
To perform complex statistical tests
To clean data using a drag-and-drop UI
To calculate the mean of large datasets

questions.text: Which tool is used to automate the deployment of applications inside lightweight containers?
options: The Excel PowerPivot tool
The Docker platform
The SQL Server Studio
The RStudio environment

questions.text: In a relational database, what is a 'Primary Key' used for?
options: To encrypt the data in a column
To uniquely identify each record
To sort data in descending order
To connect to an external server

questions.text: Which framework is developed by Google for high-performance numerical computation and deep learning?
options: The PyTorch framework
The TensorFlow library
The Keras high-level API
The Scipy scientific tool

questions.text: What does a 'NoSQL' database typically prioritize over a traditional SQL database?
options: Strict adherence to fixed schemas
Scalability and flexible data models
Complex multi-table join operations
Small-scale local storage only

questions.text: Which command in Python is used to install third-party packages from the Python Package Index (PyPI)?
options: The 'install' command
The 'pip' command
The 'get' command
The 'run' command

questions.text: Who is often considered the 'Father of Artificial Intelligence' and proposed the 'Turing Test'?
options: Bill Gates of Microsoft
Alan Turing, the mathematician
Elon Musk of Tesla/SpaceX
Steve Jobs of Apple Inc.

questions.text: Which type of AI is designed to perform a single, specific task (like playing chess or facial recognition)?
options: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)
Narrow AI or Weak AI
Artificial Super Intelligence (ASI)
Self-Awareness AI Systems

questions.text: What is the 'Turing Test' designed to evaluate in a machine?
options: The mathematical speed of the processor
The ability to exhibit intelligent behavior
The memory capacity of the hard drive
The efficiency of the power consumption

questions.text: What does 'NLP' stand for in the context of Artificial Intelligence?
options: Natural Linear Programming
Natural Language Processing
Network Logic Protocol
Neural Learning Path

questions.text: In AI, what is a 'Neural Network' modeled after?
options: The structure of a solar system
The biological human brain
The layout of a city's traffic
The design of a modern factory

questions.text: Which field of AI deals specifically with giving machines the ability to 'see' and interpret visual data?
options: Machine Translation field
Computer Vision field
Speech Recognition field
Recommender Systems field

questions.text: What is 'Generative AI' primarily used for?
options: Deleting old data from a cloud server
Creating new content like text or images
Calculating the mean of a dataset
Protecting computers from virus attacks

questions.text: Which term describes an AI's ability to learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed?
options: Hardware acceleration
Machine Learning
Database management
Scripted automation

questions.text: What is the primary goal of 'Artificial General Intelligence' (AGI)?
options: To beat humans at a specific board game
To perform any intellectual task a human can
To replace all human jobs with robots
To create a perfectly secure firewall

questions.text: Which of these is a real-world application of AI in the healthcare industry?
options: Printing paper receipts for patients
Analyzing medical images for early diagnosis
Cleaning floors in the hospital lobby
Scheduling vacations for nurses and doctors

questions.text: What is a 'Chatbot' in the context of AI applications?
options: A robot that walks and talks in person
A program that simulates human conversation
A type of computer screen for data entry
A database that stores user passwords

questions.text: Which of these is an example of 'Narrow AI'?
options: An AI that can write poetry and code
An email spam filter algorithm
A hypothetical sentient computer
A robot with human-like consciousness

questions.text: What does 'Expert Systems' refer to in the history of AI?
options: Programs that use rules to solve problems
The most powerful supercomputers today
People who are hired to train models
The hardware used to build robots

questions.text: Which concept describes the 'black box' problem in AI?
options: The difficulty in explaining AI decisions
The physical case that holds a computer
A specific type of encrypted database
The loss of power during model training

questions.text: What is an 'Agent' in Artificial Intelligence terminology?
options: A person who sells AI software
An entity that perceives and acts on environment
A secret code used to unlock a model
A government official who regulates AI

questions.text: In 'Supervised Learning', what is required during the training process?
options: No prior data labels or target values
A dataset with known input-output pairs
A human operator to click every button
A constant connection to a live website

questions.text: Which machine learning type is used when the model learns through trial and error using rewards?
options: Unsupervised Learning method
Reinforcement Learning method
Clustering and Grouping method
Statistical Association method

questions.text: What is the main task of 'Unsupervised Learning'?
options: Predicting the exact price of a stock
Finding hidden patterns in unlabeled data
Translating text from English to French
Labeling images as 'cat' or 'dog' correctly

questions.text: Which algorithm is commonly used for classification by finding the 'nearest' neighbors?
options: The K-Means clustering algorithm
The K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm
The Linear Regression algorithm
The Apriori association algorithm

questions.text: What is 'Clustering' in machine learning used for?
options: Predicting a continuous numeric value
Grouping similar data points together
Ordering data points by their importance
Deleting data points that are too close

questions.text: Which of these is a typical task for a 'Regression' model?
options: Classifying an email as spam or not spam
Predicting the temperature for tomorrow
Identifying human faces in a photograph
Grouping customers based on their hobbies

questions.text: What is a 'Decision Tree' in machine learning?
options: A literal plant used to produce oxygen
A flowchart-like structure for making choices
A list of all variables in a database
A type of server rack for AI processing

questions.text: What does 'Deep Learning' utilize to process complex data?
options: A single layer of linear regression
Multiple layers of artificial neurons
Only manual input from expert humans
A simple list of if-then-else rules

questions.text: In a neural network, what is the purpose of an 'Activation Function'?
options: To turn off the computer after training
To introduce non-linearity into the model
To store the weights in a permanent file
To increase the speed of data transmission

questions.text: Which term describes the process of a model learning the training data too well?
options: Under-training the model
Overfitting the model
Optimizing the model
Generalizing the model

questions.text: What is the 'Cost Function' (or Loss Function) used for in training?
options: To calculate the total price of the project
To measure the error of the model's prediction
To count the number of features in a dataset
To determine the salary of the AI engineers

questions.text: What is 'Gradient Descent' primarily used for?
options: Visualizing data in three dimensions
Minimizing the loss function during training
Encrypting the weights of a neural network
Downloading data from a remote server

questions.text: Which of these is an example of a 'Classification' problem?
options: Estimating the future price of a house
Predicting if a credit card charge is fraud
Calculating the average height of a group
Finding the sum of a column in Excel

questions.text: What is 'Semi-Supervised Learning'?
options: Learning with only half of the features
Using a small amount of labeled data with much unlabeled data
Learning only during the daytime hours
A human and a computer working together

questions.text: Which algorithm is a collection of many decision trees?
options: The Support Vector Machine
The Random Forest algorithm
The Logistic Regression model
The Principal Component analysis

questions.text: How do AI systems 'perceive' the physical world in robotics?
options: Through feelings and human emotions
Through sensors like cameras and LiDAR
By reading books and digital manuals
By following a strict pre-written script

questions.text: What is 'Knowledge Representation' in the context of AI?
options: How a computer physically stores memory
How information is structured for an AI to use
The amount of data a human can memorize
The process of printing reports on paper

questions.text: Which of these is a method for 'Reasoning' in AI systems?
options: Logical deduction from known premises
Randomly guessing the next possible step
Waiting for a human to provide the answer
Deleting data until a solution is found

questions.text: What is a 'Knowledge Graph' used for in AI?
options: To plot the performance of a CPU
To represent complex relationships between entities
To draw a bar chart of sales data
To track the location of robots in a warehouse

questions.text: What does 'Computer Vision' enable an AI to do?
options: Understand and generate human speech
Identify and process objects in images
Calculate large numbers very quickly
Predict the outcome of a coin toss

questions.text: What is 'Heuristic Search' in AI problem-solving?
options: Searching through every possible option
Using 'rules of thumb' to find solutions faster
Asking a user to search on the internet
A search that never reaches a conclusion

questions.text: Which concept deals with AI making decisions based on 'if-then' logic?
options: Deep learning with neural networks
Rule-based reasoning systems
Probabilistic clustering methods
Generative adversarial networks

questions.text: What is 'Image Segmentation' in computer vision?
options: Compressing an image into a smaller file
Dividing an image into multiple meaningful parts
Changing the color of an image to black and white
Rotating an image by 90 degrees clockwise

questions.text: In AI, what is a 'Semantic Network'?
options: A high-speed fiber optic internet connection
A graphic representation of knowledge and logic
A group of social media users talking online
The internal wiring of a modern supercomputer

questions.text: What does 'OCR' stand for in the context of data perception?
options: Online Computer Resource
Optical Character Recognition
Open Code Repository
Optimal Cluster Range

questions.text: Which method is used for an AI to find the best path in a game or map?
options: The A* (A-Star) search algorithm
The Linear Regression analysis
The K-Means clustering technique
The Standard Deviation calculation

questions.text: What is 'Probabilistic Reasoning' in AI?
options: Reasoning when all facts are 100% certain
Reasoning that accounts for uncertainty and chance
Reasoning that only uses prime numbers
Reasoning that always gives the same answer

questions.text: What is 'Feature Extraction' in perception tasks?
options: Deleting the most important data from a set
Identifying key characteristics from raw input
Adding new features that were never there
Naming the variables in a Python script

questions.text: What is the 'Frame Problem' in Artificial Intelligence?
options: The cost of building a metal case for a robot
The difficulty of representing changes in a world
The time it takes to refresh a computer monitor
The way images are cropped in a vision system

questions.text: What is 'Speech-to-Text' technology an example of?
options: A reasoning system for math problems
A perception system for audio data
A storage system for large text files
A security system for bank accounts

questions.text: What is 'Algorithmic Bias' in AI systems?
options: The speed at which an algorithm runs
Unfair outcomes caused by the training data
The cost of developing a new AI model
The type of programming language used

questions.text: Which regulation governs data privacy and protection in the European Union?
options: The HIPAA regulation
The GDPR regulation
The FERPA regulation
The COPPA regulation

questions.text: What is 'Explainable AI' (XAI)?
options: AI that can speak multiple human languages
AI designed so humans can understand its logic
AI that is free for everyone to use online
AI that can write its own documentation

questions.text: Which concept describes the ethical issue of AI replacing human workers?
options: Data persistence issues
Job displacement and automation
Algorithmic complexity problems
Hardware sustainability concerns

questions.text: What is 'Deepfake' technology?
options: A very secure way to store user passwords
AI-generated media that replaces a person's likeness
A type of model that only works on deep data
A method for finding fake accounts on social media

questions.text: In AI ethics, what does 'Transparency' refer to?
options: Being able to see the internal hardware
Being open about how an AI system functions
Making the AI interface clear and see-through
Publishing the names of all the programmers

questions.text: What is a 'Hallucination' in Large Language Models (LLMs)?
options: When the AI stops responding to prompts
When the AI generates false or illogical info
When the computer starts to overheat
When the user forgets their login password

questions.text: What is 'Differential Privacy' used for?
options: Making AI models run significantly faster
Sharing data insights without revealing individuals
Comparing two different privacy policies
Restricting AI access to only certain countries

questions.text: Which of these is an example of an AI safety concern?
options: The AI using too much electrical power
The AI making decisions that harm humans
The AI having a very boring personality
The AI being unable to play video games

questions.text: What does 'Informed Consent' mean in data collection?
options: Users agree to data use after being told the risks
The computer automatically clicks 'Accept' for users
Users are forced to give data to use a service
A user finds out their data was used after the fact

questions.text: Which ethical principle suggests AI should benefit humanity and do no harm?
options: The principle of Profitability
The principle of Beneficence
The principle of Complexity
The principle of Scalability

questions.text: What is the 'Social Credit System' often cited as a concern for in AI?
options: Increasing the speed of credit card processing
Mass surveillance and loss of individual freedom
Improving the accuracy of weather forecasts
Providing more storage for social media photos

questions.text: What is 'Data Sovereignty'?
options: The idea that data is subject to laws of its country
The total amount of data a king or queen owns
A type of AI that can rule a small nation
The ability to move data between different clouds

questions.text: Which of these is a risk of 'Autonomous Weapons'?
options: They might run out of battery mid-flight
They could make lethal decisions without human input
They are too expensive for most countries to buy
They require too much internet bandwidth to work

questions.text: What is 'Anonymization' in data processing?
options: Adding a user's full name to every record
Removing identifying information from a dataset
Enciphering data so only one person can see it
Selling data to a third-party marketing firm

questions.text: What is the primary difference between 'Structured' and 'Unstructured' data?
options: Structured data is always larger than unstructured
Structured data follows a predefined data model
Unstructured data can only be stored on paper
Structured data is only used by AI researchers

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of 'Categorical' (qualitative) data?
options: A person's height in centimeters
The color of a car (Red, Blue, Green)
The price of a gallon of gasoline
The number of students in a classroom

questions.text: What does the 'Data Wrangling' (or Munging) stage of a project involve?
options: Presenting final results to a group of executives
Cleaning and transforming raw data for analysis
Buying more hard drives to store the information
Hiring new data scientists to join the company

questions.text: Which number system uses only the digits 0 and 1?
options: The Decimal system
The Binary system
The Hexadecimal system
The Octal system

questions.text: In the data science process, which step typically follows 'Data Collection'?
options: Deploying the model to the public
Data Cleaning and exploration
Writing the final project report
Archiving the data for ten years

questions.text: What is 'Metadata' often described as?
options: Data that has been deleted by mistake
Data that provides information about other data
Data that is extremely large and complex
Data that is encrypted for high security

questions.text: Which of these is a common source of 'Big Data'?
options: A single handwritten diary from 1950
Social media feeds and sensor networks
A small local library's card catalog
A student's personal grocery list

questions.text: What is 'Data Ethics'?
options: The speed at which data is transferred online
The moral principles of data use and collection
A type of programming for data scientists
The cost of buying data from a provider

questions.text: Convert the decimal number 10 into binary format.
What is 'Quantitative Data'?
options: Data that describes qualities or characteristics
Data that can be measured and expressed in numbers
Data that is only found in scientific journals
Data that cannot be stored on a computer

questions.text: What is the 'Data Life Cycle'?
options: The time it takes to download a large file
The stages data goes through from creation to deletion
The battery life of a data storage device
The number of years a data scientist works

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of 'Semi-Structured' data?
options: A standard SQL database table
A JSON or XML file with tags
A printed book in a library
A voice recording of a meeting

questions.text: What is a 'Data Warehouse' used for?
options: To physically store thousands of hard drives
To centrally store integrated data for reporting
To manufacture new computer components
To house the offices of a data science team

questions.text: In data science, what is 'Data Provenance'?
options: The total cost of a data project
The record of the origin and history of data
The speed of the database connection
The language used to write the model

questions.text: What does 'Big Data' typically involve (the 3 Vs)?
